abstract.p: Elizabeth Judd reviews novel The Cave by Tim Krabbe (S)

block.p: Tim Krabbe's new novel is a psychological thriller, a study in political corruption and, most improbably, a tender coming-of-age story in which fate binds the restless characters with an inevitability that may remind readers of Thomas Hardy's fiction. ''The Cave'' opens as a geologist named Egon Wagter is transporting a mysterious suitcase to Ratanakiri, a fictitious third-world dictatorship. Krabbe skips around in time and place: we're taken to the summer camp in Belgium where Egon first met Axel van de Graaf, the charming criminal who masterminded the suitcase handoff; to an impoverished district in Ratanakiri where a young man will be beheaded for a bungled crime; and to a Massachusetts town where a housewife plans a surreptitious escape. Giving away more would do disservice to Krabbe's carefully constructed narrative, which has a geometry so precise that the patterns buried under the surface emerge only in the final pages. Krabbe -- who is also the author of ''The Golden Egg,'' a creepy thriller that was made into the film ''The Vanishing'' -- writes deft and unsentimental prose, and the low-key elegance of his tale comes through in Sam Garrett's lovely translation from the Dutch.
